raw_text:
Labour's Cunningham to stand down
 
 Veteran Labour MP and former Cabinet minister Jack Cunningham has said he will stand down at the next election.
 
 One of the few Blair-era ministers to serve under Jim Callaghan, he was given the agriculture portfolio when Labour regained power in 1997. Mr Cunningham went on to become Tony Blair's "cabinet enforcer". He has represented the constituency now known as Copeland since 1970. Mr Blair said he was a "huge figure" in Labour and a "valued, personal friend".
 
 During Labour's long period in opposition, Mr Cunningham held a number of shadow roles including foreign affairs, the environment and as trade spokesman. As agriculture minister he caused controversy when he decided to ban beef on the bone in the wake of fears over BSE. He quit the government in 1999 and in recent years has served as the chairman of the all-party committee on Lords reform and has been a loyal supporter of the government from the backbenches.
llama3.2:1b: Jack Cunningham will stand down at the next election, a veteran Labour MP who held several key roles including agriculture minister under Tony Blair.

He was a key figure under Jim Callaghan and Tony Blair, serving as agriculture minister and trade spokesman during Labour's opposition period.

He served in various ministerial positions under Blair and Callaghan, including agriculture minister, where he caused controversy with the ban on beef on the bone.

He was Blair's cabinet enforcer during Labour's long opposition period.

The Labour Party faced controversy when he banned beef on the bone after fears over BSE.
He quit in 1999, has been a loyal supporter of the government from their backbenches, and now serves as chairman for Lords reform.

During Labour's long period in opposition, Mr Cunningham held various shadow roles including foreign affairs, the environment and as trade spokesman.
As agriculture minister, he banned beef on the bone in response to fears over BSE.
He quit the government in 1999 and has served as the chairman of the all-party committee on Lords reform.

Mr Cunningham said he was a "huge figure" in Labour and a "valued, personal friend" to Tony Blair.
As a cabinet minister, he caused controversy by banning beef on the bone in the wake of fears over BSE (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy).
He quit the government in 1999 but has served as the chairman of the all-party committee on Lords reform and has been a loyal supporter of the government from the backbenches.

He was appointed agriculture minister under Tony Blair in 1997 and served in this position until 2004.
During his time as trade spokesperson, CuNNHAMBURG caused controversy when he banned beef on the boneless cuts of meat during concerns over BSE.

tinydolphin:1.1b: Summarized: Jack Cunningham, Labour's veteran MP and Cabinet Minister under Tony Blair, announced his intention to step down at the next election, stating his decision is based on his contributions to the party, but also highlighting his impact on policy areas like agriculture and foreign affairs.

Currently serving as chairman of the all-party committee on Lords Reform, Jack Cunningham has been a loyal supporter of the government since his resignation in 1999.
